comments.body:
```
In ./hack/make-rules/verify.sh line 84:
EXCLUDED_CHECKS=$(ls ${EXCLUDED_PATTERNS[@]/#/${KUBE_ROOT}\/hack\/} 2>/dev/null || true)
                     ^-- SC2068: Double quote array expansions to avoid re-splitting elements.

In ./hack/make-rules/verify.sh line 85:
QUICK_CHECKS=$(ls ${QUICK_PATTERNS[@]/#/${KUBE_ROOT}\/hack\/} 2>/dev/null || true)
                  ^-- SC2068: Double quote array expansions to avoid re-splitting elements.
```

When adding only double quotation, EXCLUDED_CHECKS/QUICK_CHECKS are handled as string not array.
So, is-excluded/is-quick functions cannot work properly.
Therefore, I changed these lines as the above
confirmed this works locally
This should be coming in from `lib/util.sh`, I would rather we understand why that's not getting sourced in such that these are visible, rather than defend against them being unassigned

comments.body: to echo what I said in person: I also wonder if it'd be better to pass a space-separated list of patterns to skip, rather than adding envvars for each type of check here
to follow up on in-person conversation: it probably makes sense to add environment variables for these group of things, since we might factor out codegen checks next.

comments.body: When would this be true? Isn't it checked in to the repo as well?

It is. I don't know why this wouldn't trigger, but I had copied it from here: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/884e4b7b9c63a9a3b94278972d640454b8d16e47/hack/make-rules/test-cmd-util.sh#L82-L89
Maybe we can drop it then, seems like a bit of a cargo cult situation :D

> seems like a bit of a cargo cult situation :D

\- @stevekuznetsov describing 90% of bash 😄
If we're running with `set -o errexit` on why does this work?

we capture the status when calling `run-cmd`, which is why the script doesn't fully exit on failures here.

I don't think we need to do this `tr=$?` and `return ${tr}` stuff, though - we can keep it as it was before; the correct status should be returned regardless.
@ixdy It [wasn't returning the status](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/58783#issuecomment-360375698), so these were added.
wait, how did this ever work?
✨bash✨

comments.body:
@soltysh - if remove this here, it will not get run in the jenkins job (Example https://storage.googleapis.com/kubernetes-jenkins/pr-logs/pull/29185/kubernetes-pull-verify-all/4827/build-log.txt)

So if we need to remove it here, we need to figure out how to run this target in the CI job.
This currently complains being called directly due to it's current construction. We should call `make vet` directly in that case. Lemme update the PR.
Or I'll update the `verify` target appropriately.
I don't understand this part.  It seems to be a net no-change, why?

If you look into [verify-govet.sh](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/hack/verify-govet.sh) you'll notice the script will complain that it should not be called directly, but rather through `make vet`. So I've moved that call from here to `make verify` directly, which calls `hack/make-rules/vet.sh` which does not complain about not being called directly.

  )
